newsitem.title: USA: Clinton asks for farm loan extension authority.
newsitem.headline: Clinton asks for farm loan extension authority.

text.p: President Clinton proposed as part of his fiscal 1998 budget Thursday to allow a six-month extension of commodity loans "during periods of severe market disruptions."

The proposal was part of a handful of suggestions to improve the safety net for farmers. Others included limited haying and grazing on Conservation Reserve land and authority to sell farm revenue insurance nationwide.
The Agriculture Secretary has hinted for weeks that the budget might ask for longer loan periods for farmers. USDA considered, but did not seek, a new on-farm grain reserve.

There has been little recent support on Capitol Hill for loan extensions. A small number of senators joined Democratic Leader Tom Daschle in filing a bill with a five-month extension and removal of the cap on loan rates.
The budget asked for "discretionary authority to extend commodity loans for six months during periods of severe market disruptions."
